title.narrative: 3.2. MNCAH POLICY AND BUDGETING

description.narrative: 3.2. By 2020, national authorities have increased capacity to formulate evidence-based regulatory framework and budgets for key MNCAH packages of interventions, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Adolescent Health And Nutrition (Covid), Child Health, Child Health (Covid), Early Childhood Development, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Equitable Access To Quality Education (Covid), Hiv Prevention, Hiv â€“ General, Immunization, Maternal And Newborn Health, Maternal And Newborn Health (Covid), Nutrition â€“ General, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Sanitation, Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 3.By 2020 mothers and children, especially the most vulnerable , have access to quality healthcare services (individual and population based), including in emergency

sector.narrative: Capacity building for nutrition preparedness and response
Community and home based maternal and newborn care
Data, research, evaluation, evidence generation, synthesis, and use for prevention of stunting and other forms of malnutrition
Facility based maternal and newborn care (including emergency obstetric and newborn care, quality improvement)
HIV health and community system strengthening to improve access and adherence
Immunization supply chain, including cold chain
Maternal and newborn care policy advocacy, evidence generation, national / subnational capacity development
PMTCT program support such as retention in care, family planning, infant feeding, infant medical male circumcision and community facility linkages
Public health emergencies, including disease outbreaks
Sanitation and hygiene - institutions (schools, health care facilities, ECD centres) including menstrual hygiene management
System strengthening - risk informed programming, including climate, resilience, disaster, conflict, and emergency preparedness
Technical assistance - Immunization (excluding Polio technical assistance)
Technical assistance - Maternal and newborn health

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 3.2. By 2020, national authorities have increased capacity to formulate evidence-based regulatory framework and budgets for keyMNCAH packages of interventions

description.narrative: National maternal and child nutrition improvement plan;was;developed;and approved which incorporates nationwide replication of home visiting programme piloted by UNICEF. Sustainability of upgraded immunization;programme;was ensured through;appropriate budgeting of vaccine procurement and cold chain equipment maintenance.;Home visiting guides are adapted to Uzbekistan context. A total of 95,000 children;aged 6-59;months have;benefitted from two rounds of UNICEF supported Vitamin A supplementation.;More than 6;million;children in basic schools, 1.400 000 pre-school children and 2 million parents gained critical knowledge and information on the hygiene for infection prevention and control during COVID-19 and beyond. | Status:Met | As-of Date:22/01/2021
